banner.text: OK! Final challenge. We’re going to put everything together to make a paint splatter based on how fast your move the mouse.
We’re using the mouse again. Start by clicking 'Add Parts'.

tooltips.text: Click on Mouse to add it to your app

banner.text: Open this tray
Drag the block onto your code space
Connect it to the app starts event.
Pick a dark background color. Black works really well!
Let’s set the mouse cursor to a paint brush. Open the mouse tray.
Grab the set cursor block.
Connect it up.
To make the cursor into a little paintbrush, change animals to other …
… and change Avocado to paintbrush
Open the Control tray to find a loop.
Grab the Every 1 second loop.
Connect it up.
To make the loop run fast, change seconds to frames.
Now for the paint color. Open the Draw tray.
Drag the fill color block into your code …
… and connect it up inside the loop.
Click the fill color color picker and select a bright color. Yellow works really well!
OK. The next bit uses some really clever maths. In order to know how fast the mouse is moving, we need to do some trigonometry. Ready?
Open the Variables tray.
Grab the set variable block …
… and connect it inside your loop.
Change item to distance.
Open the Math tray.
Grab the square root block.
Connect it to your variable.
Open the Math tray again.
This block lets you add two numbers together. Grab it!
Connect it to your square root block.
Open the Math tray again.
Grab another of those adding blocks.
This bit’s tricky. Connect the block inside the first input.
Change + to × multiply.
Now open the Mouse tray.
Grab the X speed block.
Connect it inside the multiplication block.
Open the Mouse tray to get another one of those blocks.
Grab another X speed block.
Connect it to the other input. (This will multiply the mouse X position by itself).
Open the Math tray train again!
Grab another of these math blocks.
Connect it inside the other input.
Change + to × multiply.
Open the Mouse tray.
This time, grab the Y speed block.
Plug it into your second multiplication block.
Last bit of the trigonometry equation, open the mouse tray again.
Grab another Y speed block.
Plug it into the last gap.
OK! That’s a long line of code. It works out how far the mouse has travelled in the last frame and saves it in the distance variable.
Now to use that distance! Open the logic tray.
Drag the if block to your code.
Connect it under your trigonometry blocks.
Open the Logic tray again …
… and grab this block, which is called a comparator.
Connect it to the if block.
Change = to > greater than.
Open the Variables tray.
Grab this block. It returns the little piece of data stored in the variable.
Connect it to the first space in your if block.
Change the variable block from item to distance
Open the Variables tray gain.
Bring in one of these number blocks.
Connect it into the second gap of the if block.
Change 0 to 15
Now this line of code checks to see if the value of your distance variable is greater than 15. When it is, the next code runs.
Let’s write the code that will run when the if statement is true. Open the Control tray.
Drag the repeat block into your code.
Connect it inside your if block.
Change 10 to 15.
Open the draw tray.
Drag the move to block into your code.
Connect it inside the repeat loop.
You’re going to move the drawing pen to the mouse cursor. Open the mouse tray.
Drag the X position block onto your code space.
Plug it into the move to X.
Now for the Y position. Open the Mouse tray again.
Grab the Y position block.
Plug it into the move to Y input.
You’ve moved the drawing pen to the mouse. Now we’ll move it again based on the speed of the mouse. This will create the cool paint splatter effect we want!
Open the Variables tray.
Grab the set variable block.
Connect it inside your repeat loop.
Change item to randomness.
Open the Math tray.
Grab a random number block.
Connect it to your randomness variable.
Change the second number from 10 to 25.
Open the draw tray.
Drag the move by block. This block moves your cursor along and down from its current position.
Connect it inside your loop, under randomness.
Open the Math tray.
Grab the math block.
Connect it to the move by x input.
Change + to ÷ divide.
Open the Mouse tray.
Drag the X speed block to your code.
Connect it in the first math input.
Now we need another math block. Open the tray again.
Grab the math block.
Connect it inside the second math input.
Change + to ÷ divide
Open the Variables tray.
Grab the variable block.
Connect it into the left hand input.
Change item to randomness.
Open the Variables tray to find a simple number block.
Drag the number block in.
Connect it to the second input.
Change 0 to 7.
Now for the Y value. Open the Math tray again.
Just like for the X value. Grab a math block.
Connect it to move by y input.
Change + to ÷ divide
Open the Mouse tray.
This time you need the mouse Y speed.
Connect it to the left hand input.
Open the Math tray.
Drag another math block into your code.
Connect it to the second input.
Change + to ÷ divide.
Open the Variables tray.
Grab the variable block.
Connect it to to the left input.
Change the drop down from item to randomness.
Open the Variables tray again.
Drag the number block to your code space.
Plug it into the right input.
Change 0 to 7.
Now the pen is in position based on the mouse location and speed. Here’s a cool trick though: move it again by a random number to put it in a different place every time the repeat block loops.
Open the draw tray.
Drag in another move by block.
Connect it inside the repeat loop.
Open the Math tray to find a random number block.
Drag the random number block into your code.
Connect it to to the move by x input.
Change the first value from 0 to -5.
Change the second value from 10 to 5.
Now for the y input. Open the math tray again.
Drag in another random number block.
Connect it to the move by y input.
Change the left value from 0 to -5.
Change the right value from 10 to 5.
Now you're ready to draw the paint! Open the draw tray.
Grab the draw circle block.
Connect it in the repeat loop.
One last bit of maths to set the size of the circles you draw. These should get smaller the further they are from the brush (just like paint splatters would). Open the math tray.
Drag the math block into your code.
Connect it to the circle radius input.
Change + to ÷ divide.
You’re going to use the distnace we calculated earlier to set the circle radius. Open the Variables tray.
Grab the variable block.
Connect it to the left math input.
Change the variable from item to randomness
Open the Variables tray again to get a simple number block.
Grab the simple number block.
Connect it to the right math input.
Change 0 to 4.
Ready to try it out? Move your mouse quickly on the canvas to splatter some paint! What happens if you draw lots of really fast circles?
Congratulations! You've completed the Street Artist challenges! Keep saving new creations for more chances to win. You can enter as many times as you want!
